image.altText: For Sale signage outside a suburban house.

items.synopsis: After a brief downturn earlier in the year, Australia's housing market is firmly in recovery mode, with CoreLogic data showing house prices increased for a sixth consecutive month in August.

title.children: House prices rise for sixth straight month, with interest rate outlook likely to see 'active' selling season

image.altText: People on a street hold up signs protesting against the release of wastewater from the Fukushima nuclear plant.

items.synopsis: Japanese businesses and citizens living in China suffer a backlash following the release of treated radioactive wastewater from the damaged Fukushima nuclear power plant.

title.children: Japan started releasing nuclear wastewater into the Pacific last week. The reaction in China has been swift

image.altText: Two men with greying hair in suits shake hands on a street watched by other people

items.synopsis: Australia's only Liberal premier is actively campaigning with a Labor prime minister for a Yes vote on a Voice to Parliament, while some of Tasmania's Aboriginal groups are hoping the No vote succeeds.

title.children: Tasmania is the smallest state — but could play a big part as Voice campaign rolls on

image.altText: A person holds a Voice to Parliament official referendum booklet

items.synopsis: The Voice to Parliament campaign is already rife with misinformation. Here are some eyebrow-raising claims you may have seen about the referendum and how you can help ABC Investigations expose more like them.

title.children: Do these claims about the Voice raise an eyebrow? Here's what they're actually about

image.altText: Australiam Army soldiers stand at attention during an Anzac Day parade

items.synopsis: Hundreds of soldiers could be moved out of South Australia under a planned restructure of the army, with the Department of Defence considering options on how best to transform the service for future "littoral" operations.

title.children: Army considers removing Adelaide-based units

image.altText: A close up street view of an old Japanese house next to an apartment building.

items.synopsis: How does Tokyo's property market compare to Australia's? Here are four unique lessons, from loose zoning laws to smaller dwelling sizes, an advanced public transport system and an openness to development.

title.children: The four unique ways Tokyo approaches housing can offer lessons for Australia

image.altText: An aerial image shows a volcanic island emitting white smoke surrounded by clear blue sea on a clear day.

items.synopsis: James, Andrew and Peter Buttle apply to have the charges they are facing over the deadly 2019 eruption of their volcano dismissed.

title.children: Brothers who inherited NZ volcano ask judge to drop charges, claiming 'this is not a prosecution of a family'

image.altText: A man with tattoos and sunglasses speaks into a microphone; Mitch Mcconnell stares at something offscreen

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Ex-Proud Boys leader gets 17 years over Capitol Riot, doctor says Mitch McConnell 'medically clear'. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Voice debate has been mired in misinformation, including unfounded claims around land rights, misleadingly edited videos, and accusations of voter fraud. ABC Investigations wants to know if you think you've seen or received materials containing misinformation. You can let us know here. You can also see some of the claims about the Voice debunked here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Tackling misinformation on the Voice

featuredLink.title: Do these claims about the Voice raise an eyebrow?

children.content: The Voice debate has been mired in misinformation, including unfounded claims around land rights, misleadingly edited videos, and accusations of voter fraud.
ABC Investigations
wants to know if you think you've seen or received materials containing misinformation.
You can let us know
here
You can also see some of the claims about the Voice debunked here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A federal judge has sentenced former far-right Proud Boys leader Joseph Biggs to 17 years in prison for his role in storming the US Capitol in a failed bid to overturn Donald Trump's 2020 election defeat. Ahead of his sentencing, Biggs apologised for his actions as he faced the judge, choking up as he spoke about his daughter whom he said was a sexual assault victim who needed him. "I was seduced by the crowd, and I just moved forward. My curiosity got the better of me," Biggs said. "I'm not a terrorist. I don't have hate in my heart." There are multiple former Proud Boys being sentenced this morning, so we'll have more updates on that for you shortly.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Seduced by the crowd': Former Proud Boys leader sentenced

children.content: A federal judge has sentenced former far-right Proud Boys leader
Joseph Biggs
to 17 years in prison for his role in storming the US Capitol in a failed bid to overturn
Donald Trump's 2020 election defeat.

props.alt: A man in  a mask takes a selfie inside the US Senate

children.content: Joseph Biggs seen inside the Senate Gallery on January 6, 2021.
(Image: Justice Department)
Ahead of his sentencing, Biggs apologised for his actions as he faced the judge, choking up as he spoke about his daughter whom he said was a sexual assault victim who needed him.
"I was seduced by the crowd, and I just moved forward. My curiosity got the better of me," Biggs said. "I'm not a terrorist. I don't have hate in my heart."
There are multiple former Proud Boys being sentenced this morning, so we'll have more updates on that for you shortly.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: US Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell has been medically cleared to continue with his schedule by Congress's doctor. It follows a second incident in which Senator McConnell was speaking to reporters when he froze for more than 30 seconds. The congressional physician said in a statement that he had consulted with Senator McConnell and his neurology team and had evaluated the incident. "I have informed Leader McConnell that he is medically clear to continue with his schedule as planned," the statement says. "Occasional lightheadedness is not uncommon in concussion recovery and can also be expected as a result of dehydration." The 81-year-old was out of the Senate for almost six weeks this year after he fell and hit his head. At a July media conference, the Kentucky senator appeared to freeze up and stared vacantly for around 20 seconds.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Mitch McConnell 'medically clear' after freezing up for second time

children.content: US Senate Republican leader
Mitch McConnell
has been medically cleared to continue with his schedule by Congress's doctor.
It follows a second incident in which Senator McConnell was speaking to reporters when he froze for more than 30 seconds.
The
congressional physician
said in a statement that he had consulted with Senator McConnell and
his neurology team
and had evaluated the incident.
"I have informed Leader McConnell that he is medically clear to continue with his schedule as planned," the statement says.
"Occasional lightheadedness is not uncommon in concussion recovery and can also be expected as a result of dehydration."
The 81-year-old was out of the Senate for almost six weeks this year after he fell and hit his head.
At a July media conference, the Kentucky senator appeared to freeze up and stared vacantly for around 20 seconds.

image.altText: Close up shot of Anthony Albanese.

items.synopsis: Thank goodness for Senate committees. This week, they've proved, yet again, to be worth their weight in accountability gold, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: It can be a battle to get information from the Albanese government

image.altText: A woman is photographed from the neck down, walking with a plastic Woolworths shopping bag under her arm.

items.synopsis: States and territories each set their own standards for single-use plastics — so who's leading in the race to the top?

title.children: Three states are bringing in new rules in a 'race to the top' to ban single-use plastics

image.altText: Close up of Qantas chief executive Alan Joyce speaking to the media at a press event.

items.synopsis: Qantas has confirmed it will refund $570 million worth of COVID travel credits for domestic and international customers, while the ACCC has accused the airline of selling tickets for flights it had already cancelled.

title.children: 'People lost faith in the process': Qantas scraps expiry dates on $570m worth of COVID travel credits

image.altText: A large ladder reaches at the top of the building with a firefighter in front of it

items.synopsis: One of the deadliest fires in South Africa leads to more than 74 deaths and scores of injuries, according to emergency services.

title.children: 'Sad day for the city of Johannesburg': More than 70 dead in building blaze

image.altText: Donald Trump, in suit, speaks with reporters in front of a plane that has his name on it.

items.synopsis: Former US president Donald Trump pleads not guilty to a wide-ranging Georgia criminal indictment related to his attempts to overturn his 2020 election defeat.

title.children: Trump pleads not guilty in Georgia election fraud case

image.altText: A man wearing a suit brings his hands to prayer position in front of his face

items.synopsis: Thaksin, Thailand's most famous politician, returned to his country last week after spending 15 years in self-imposed exile. Upon his arrival he was taken to prison to serve an eight-year sentence for abuse of power and conflicts of interest.

title.children: Thailand's billionaire ex-prime minister requests royal pardon after 15 years in exile

image.altText: Molina addresses a crowd while wearing a bright pink sari with black and silver beading.

items.synopsis: Getting rid of racism at work isn't just about training courses and diversity posters. Employees should be become more racially literate.

title.children: Molina faced racism at work when she came to Australia. She knows there's a better way

items.synopsis: NSW beekeepers have launched a class action over loss of business after their hives were destroyed to curb the spread of varroa mite.

title.children: Beekeepers seeking millions in damages as hives destroyed in varroa mite eradication

image.altText: Don and Gail, dressed in warm jackets, smile as they stand in front of the sea on a sunny day.

items.synopsis: The town of Korumburra in Victoria's south-east has come together to celebrate the life of Don and Gail Patterson, who police believe died from mushroom poisoning at a family lunch in July.

title.children: 'Lots of love to you all': Suspected mushroom poisoning victim's text to family revealed at memorial service

image.altText: Family and supporters wearing black t-shirts depicting Jomen as an angel

items.synopsis: Coroner Philip Urquhart finds prison staff knew about Mr Blanket's "suicide plan" eight weeks before he died and should have acted differently.

title.children: 'Chronic shortage' of safe cells enabled Indigenous man to take his own life in WA prison, coroner finds

image.altText: A baby and a young woman in a car. Both have their faces blurred.

items.synopsis: As Crystal waited, along with thousands of others, for public housing in Western Australia, her 10-month-old son Kenneth died. Advocates say her story is becoming increasingly common.

title.children: Crystal has finally been offered a place to live, but it came too late for her baby son

image.altText: Telstra payphones in Birdsville

items.synopsis: When this outback business owner's telecommunications service cut out 10 times in a day, she says even Telstra staff suggested she switch to an alternative internet provider.

title.children: Bush residents ditching Telstra amid claims outback services are only 'getting worse'

image.altText: A wooden cross worn on a purple shirt

items.synopsis: A bishop in regional Western Australia has apologised to Aboriginal people, and acknowledged Anglicans likely took part in "shameful betrayals and massacres".

title.children: Country bishop apologises to Indigenous people for past 'pain and violence', acknowledges massacres

image.altText: An drilling machine on a lake, blue sky with clouds, a drill in themiddle and two small boats on the side.

items.synopsis: A review of Gold Fields, which runs four mines in Australia,  has found that 47 per cent of its global workforce had experienced some form of inappropriate behaviour at work.

title.children: Global gold giant apologises for 'distressing' findings of widespread sexual harassment and bullying

image.altText: A woman embraces a soldier as she celebrates in Gabon.

items.synopsis: If successful, the coup attempt in Gabon will be the eighth one since 2020 in West and Central Africa, a region that in the past decade had made strides to shed its reputation as a "coup belt".

title.children: A look at recent coups across West and Central Africa

image.altText: The 18 AFLW captains for 2023 are pictured at Marvel Stadium. Kate Hore is standing in the centre with the Premiership Cup

items.synopsis: With another season of AFLW starting tonight, Kate O'Halloran explains where to watch, how to buy tickets, and what's new this year, including the big names to change clubs.

title.children: Want more women's sport now the Matildas' run is over? Here's all you need to know about AFLW season eight

image.altText: Two men in orange shirts, one in a black vest, walk though a motorsport paddock.

items.synopsis: Oscar Piastri and Lando Norris have had success around the famous Italian circuit, and are hoping to cement their place in the constructors' championship for McLaren.

title.children: McLaren wants 'memorable' race in Italy, as Verstappen hunts F1 record

image.altText: An elephant reaches its trunk up to a container of fruit hanging from a tree. Its mouth is open

items.synopsis: A plan to bring three elephants to a South Australian zoo is now underway after donations reached more than $2 million in less than a month.

title.children: Elephant to catch 'jumbo jet' to South Australia after fundraising campaign realised
